tn.ref: The king's heart is a stream of water in the hand of Yahweh
tn.text: The writer speaks of the king's heart as if it were an irrigation ditch in a dry area through which people direct water to plants that need it. AT: "Yahweh controls the king's heart as a man directs water for irrigation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The heart is a metaphor for what a person thinks and what he wants to do. AT: "The king's thoughts and actions" or "What the king thinks and what he wants to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Every person's way is right in his own eyes
tn.text: The word "eyes" is a metonym for the way a person thinks about right and wrong. The writer speaks of what a person does as if it that person were walking down a path. AT: "Every person thinks that what he does is good" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The writer speaks of Yahweh deciding whether a person desires to do what is right as if Yahweh were looking at a physical object and deciding whether it is of good quality. AT: "who will judge the motives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"To do what Yahweh thinks is right"
"To treat people the way Yahweh wants people to treat other people"

tn.ref: just is more acceptable to Yahweh
tn.text: "just—Yahweh wants this more"

tn.ref: Haughty eyes and a proud heart
tn.text: The words "eyes" and "heart" are synecdoches for a person who considers himself better than other people and wants other people to know it. AT: "People who want others to think that they are better than other people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This is a synecdoche for a person who wants others to know that he thinks he is better than they are. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This is a synecdoche for a person who thinks he is better than others. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The things that help the wicked are spoken of as a lamp. AT: "the things that help a wicked person like a lamp helps to see in the dark" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This nominal adjective can be translated as a noun phrase. AT: "a diligent man" or "a man who works hard" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
The abstract noun "poverty" can be translated as an adjective. AT: "only becomes poor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"Gaining wealth"
The tongue is a metonym for the words a person uses the tongue to speak. AT: "speaking lies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The writer likens the riches a person gains by lying to a mist that quickly goes away in the morning. AT: "a disappearing mist" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The writer speaks of the riches that a person gains by lying as if it were the bait in a hunter's trap; the word "snare" is a metonym for the bait that attracts the animal into the snare. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: The violence of the wicked will drag them away
tn.text: The writer speaks as though violence were a person who could drag other people away. God will punish wicked people who harm their innocent neighbors because of the violent deeds they have done. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

The abstract noun "violence" refers to violent deeds or things people do to harm their innocent neighbors. The word "wicked" is a nominal adjective that can be translated as a noun phrase, "wicked people." AT: "The violent acts wicked people do to harm their innocent neighbors" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
"take hold of them and force them to appear before God so that God can judge them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: The way of a guilty person is crooked
tn.text: This compares the way one lives to a crooked road one may travel. This is also an idiom. AT: "The way a guilty person lives is crooked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "crooked" means bent or not straight. This is a metaphor for morally wrong. AT: "wrong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Houses in those days had flat roofs. Ancient Israelites spent much time on their roofs, where it was often cooler than inside the house, and sometimes people would build a shelter large enough for a person to sleep in on one corner of the roof. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
a person who often argues or complains

tn.ref: The appetite of the wicked craves evil
tn.text: The writer speaks of a person's appetite, the physical desire for food and drink, as if it were a person who could desire something. The word "wicked" is a nominal adjective that refers to evil people; the word "evil" is a metonym for evil deeds. AT: "Evil people desire to do evil deeds just as they desire to eat and drink" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"strongly desires"

The abstract noun "kindness" can be translated as an adjective. The litotes "no kindness" can be translated positively. The phrase "his eyes" is a metonym for the person. AT: "that he is not kind" or "that he is very mean" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This can be translated in active form. AT: "When someone punishes the mocker" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"inexperienced, immature"
"the person who mocks others"

tn.ref: when the wise person is instructed
tn.text: This can be translated in active form. AT: "when someone instructs the wise person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here knowledge is spoken of as if it were an object that someone could grasp and keep for himself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Possible meanings are 1) any righteous person or 2) "Yahweh the one who is righteous."
"pays careful attention to"

tn.ref: he brings wicked people to disaster
tn.text: Here disaster is spoken of as if it were a place that someone could be brought to. AT: "he destroys them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: The one who shuts his ears to the cry of the poor
tn.text: This is an idiom. AT: "The one who will not listen when poor people ask for help" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The word "answered" is a metonym for a person hearing another person ask for help and acting to help. This can be translated in active form. AT: "no one will do anything to help him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"makes an angry person feel better so he is no longer angry"

The abstract noun "justice" can be translated as a noun phrase. These words can be translated in active form. AT: "When rulers do what is just" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: wanders from the way of understanding
tn.text: This is an idiom. AT: "no longer lives wisely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: he will rest in the assembly of the dead
tn.text: "he will remain in the assembly of dead spirits"

The word "ransom" is a metaphor for one person who takes the place of another person. Here the person who does what is wrong is punished instead of the person who does what is right. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
a person who harms those who trust him by lying and otherwise dealing falsely
"righteous people" or "honest people" or "just people"
This nominal adjective can be translated as a noun phrase. AT: "wise person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
"uses them all"
"climbs up and over the wall that surrounds the city"

tn.ref: the city of the mighty ones
tn.text: "a city in which mighty men are living" or "a city of mighty warriors" (see UDB)
This is an idiom. AT: "he destroys" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: the stronghold in which they trusted
tn.text: "the walls and towers around the city that they did not think anyone would be able to get past into the city, so they felt safe"

tn.ref: Whoever guards his mouth and tongue
tn.text: Both "mouth" and "tongue" refer to what a person says. AT: "Whoever is careful in what he says" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: The proud and haughty person ... acts with arrogant pride
tn.text: "You can expect a proud and haughty people to act with arrogant pride"
These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize how prideful the person is. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
The word "name" is a metonym for what people would call him. AT: "a mocker is what you should call him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: The desire of the lazy kills him
tn.text: The writer speaks of what a person wants as if it were a person who could kill a lazy person. Here the lazy person wants to be idle and not work. AT: "A lazy person only wants to be idle, and because of that he will die" or "A lazy person will die because he does not want to work" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
The hand is a synecdoche for the person. AT: "he refuses" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"wants greatly" or "desires strongly"

tn.ref: gives and does not hold back
tn.text: The phrase "does not hold back" can be stated positively, and what he gives can be made explicit. AT: "gives everything he should" or "gives generously" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: The sacrifice of the wicked is detestable
tn.text: The writer does not mention Yahweh here, as in [[:en:bible:notes:pro:15:07|15:8]], but the reader should understand that it is Yahweh who detests the sacrifice of the wicked.
The nominal adjective "wicked" can be translated as a noun phrase. AT: "the wicked person" or "wicked people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
"Yahweh detests the sacrifice even more"
This is because people will never forget what he said.
Possible meanings are 1) "pretends to be courageous" or 2) "will not listen to correction." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"is certain that what he does is right because he makes sure it is right before he acts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: There is no wisdom, there is no understanding, and there is no advice that
tn.text: The words "there is" are repeated to emphasize the abstract nouns "wisdom," "understanding," and "advice." Yahweh is greater than anything that anyone can know or think or say. Your language may require that you not repeat "there is no." The abstract nouns can be translated as adjectives or verbs. AT: "There is no wise person, there is no one who understands anything, and there is no one who tells others what to do who" or "There is no wisdom, understanding, or advice that" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"defeat Yahweh" or "work against what Yahweh wants to do" or "show that he is right and Yahweh is wrong"

tn.ref: The horse is prepared for the day of battle
tn.text: These words can be translated in active form. AT: "Soldiers prepare horses for the day of battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The word "day" refers to time that may be longer or shorter than a day. AT: "when there is a battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
